Authors:
Carmen Martínez-Valenzuela, Rubén Félix-Gastélum, Gabriela
Herrera-Rodríguez, Silvia Espinosa-Matías, Jesús Damián Cordero-Ramírez,
Juan Carlos Martínez-Álvarez, Ignacio Eduardo Maldonado-Mendoza
Title:
Identification of the causal agent of powdery mildew on
common bean (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) in Northern Sinaloa, Mexico.
Keywords: anamorph, fungal diseases, ITS rDNA, morphology
Abstract:
Powdery mildew of beans is a disease in Northern Sinaloa
state in Mexico, however, the identity of the causal agent, which is an
obligate parasite, has not yet been elucidated due to lacking formation
on its teleomorph. The objective of this study was to identify the
causal agent of the disease through morphometric studies of the
anamorph, and molecular techniques based on the ITS (internal
transcribed spacers) region of the ribosomal DNA. We collected ten
samples of different bean varieties that exhibited symptoms of the
disease in the Fuerte Valley during the 2006-2007 fall-winter growing
season. All samples showed conidiophores of the Pseudoidium type, whose
conidia were mainly cylindrical, and when partially collapsed, their
walls showed longitudinal wrinkling, except on their ends, where the
wall appeared almost smooth. These features, in combination with the
morphological characteristics of the anamorph, and the molecular
phylogenetic analysis, revealed that the causal fungus belongs to the
mitosporic genus Oidium subgenus Pseudoidium. Phylogenetic analysis of
the ITS rDNA region was conducted including close and distant relatives
in this group, showing that they were closely related to isolates of
Erysiphe diffusa associated to soybeans and to an Erysiphe sp.
associated to Phaseolus vulgaris.
